epigraphs.text: The forms of liberty may remain long after the spirit has vanished.
Power is most dangerous when it learns to work through the very institutions meant to restrain it.
The test of a democracy is not whether it holds elections, but whether law binds those who win them.

long_synopsis: Week 19 of Trump’s second term left the Democracy Clock at 7:59 p.m., with only a 0.2‑minute shift, yet the apparent stillness masked a coordinated deepening of executive dominance. Immigration became the sharpest edge: humanitarian parole and protected status for hundreds of thousands were revoked with Supreme Court backing, arrest quotas turned enforcement into a numbers game, and social media vetting froze student visas worldwide. Universities and public media were targeted as rival centers of authority, with Harvard stripped of contracts and foreign-student authority and NPR and PBS cut off from federal funds, even as courts issued temporary injunctions. Clemency and corporate settlements favored corrupt officials, reality‑TV fraudsters, and Boeing, while migrants and low‑status defendants faced harsher treatment. Emergency tariffs, Trump‑linked foreign deals, and policy‑tied investment products fused economic governance with personal and crony gain. Courts, state attorneys general, parents, and mass protest movements pushed back, but each act of resistance required greater effort against a presidency increasingly treating law as weapon rather than limit.
